Man gets kicked out of all you can eat buffet for eating too much
=================================================================
!
1 Sep 2017 7:58 AM GMT
Massachusetts man is suing Golden Corral Corporation for being kicked out of establishment for eating 50 pounds of food.
!
x
The welfare recipient was expelled after he spent more than seven hours on site eating a whopping 50 pounds of food, alone. (Photo: Pixabay)
Albert Flemming, from Massachusetts is suing Golden Corral Corporation for $2million for false advertising after he was thrown out of one of the chain’s restaurants by its employees.
According to witnesses, the welfare recipient was expelled after he spent more than seven hours on site eating a whopping 50 pounds of food, alone.
Despite advertising, an ‘all you can eat’ buffet, the manager seemingly lost patience at some point telling the now disgruntled customer that his meal would be free but he has to leave.
The manager’s intervention angered Flemming, and after a brief altercation between the two, he was thrown out of the establishment. Flemming went on to call the police and filed a complaint against the restaurant and says he will hold the employeed accountable for their actions.
As reported by the website 8Shit, Flemming told reporters that it was a serious injustice and he was deeply insulted. He went on to add, “With my income, I rarely go to restaurants,...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Deccan Chronicle is an Indian newspaper with a mix of national and regional coverage. While generally reliable for Indian news, it has faced scrutiny regarding sensationalism in some reporting. Overall, it has historical reliability but must be approached with caution for sensitive topics.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence directly relates to a Massachusetts man suing Golden Corral after being ejected for consuming a substantial amount of food. It explicitly connects to the claim regarding an obese man suing Golden Corral and closely mirrors the situation described in the claim, making it very relevant to the determination of truthfulness.

‘Hearty eater’ says buffet banned him, relative
===============================================
A 6-foot-3, 265-pound man says a restaurant overcharged him for his trips to the buffet line, then banned him and a relative because they're hearty eaters. A spokesman for the restaurant denies the claim.
*   
*   
*   
*   (sms:?&body=%E2%80%98Heartyeater%E2%80%99saysbuffetbannedhim,relativevianbcnews-https://www.nbcnews.com/id/wbna22477703)
Jan. 3, 2008, 12:20 AM UTC / Source: The Associated Press
A 6-foot-3, 265-pound man says a restaurant overcharged him for his trips to the buffet line, then banned him and a relative because they're hearty eaters. A spokesman for the restaurant denies the claim.
Ricky Labit, a disabled offshore worker, said he had been a regular for eight months at the Manchuria Restaurant in Houma, eating there as often as three times a week.
On his most recent visit, he said, a waitress gave him and his wife's cousin, 44-year-old Michael Borrelli, a bill for $46.40, roughly double the buffet price for two adults.
"She says, 'Y'all fat, and y'all eat too much,'" Labit said.
Labit and Borrelli said they felt discriminated against because of their size. "I was stunned, that somebody would say something like that. I ain't that fat, I only weigh 277," Borrelli said, adding that...[Content truncated]

It employs professional journalists and fact-checkers, maintains standards for news reporting, and is known for breaking major news accurately. They have resources dedicated to fact-checking and debunking misinformation, contributing to their reliability in presenting truthful news.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article discusses a lawsuit regarding discrimination based on weight at a buffet. It addresses aspects similar to the claim about the obese man suing Golden Corral, although it is about a different incident and a different restaurant. While it indicates there are legal precedents regarding buffet experiences, it does not directly connect to John Pinette's video or provide specific relevance to his lawsuit.

Query1.title: Two men banned from buffet restaurant
Query1.snippet: Dec 28, 2007 ... HOUMA -- A 49-year-old disabled offshore worker and his dining companion say they were charged double the advertised price at a Houma buffet ...

content.content:
!
HOUMA -- A 49-year-old disabled offshore worker and his dining companion say they were charged double the advertised price at a Houma buffet last week because of their weight and the amount of food they consumed.
Both men say they were also asked not to come back to the buffet after they argued with restaurant management over the bill during the Dec. 21 meal.
However, a spokesman for the restaurant’s owner said the two men were billed double in accordance with a restaurant policy that charges extra for patrons who gorge themselves exclusively on the buffet’s seafood offerings, not because of their size.
Ricky Labit, who stands 6-foot, 3-inches and weighs 265 pounds, said he and his wife’s cousin, 44-year-old Michael Borrelli, had just tucked into their first plate at Manchuria Restaurant on Grand Caillou Road when the waitress dropped a bill on their table for $46.40, roughly double what the buffet would have cost for two adults.
"She says, 'Y’all fat, and y’all eat too much,’ " Labit said, adding that he had been a regular patron of the buffet restaurant, visiting as often as three times a week for the last eight months.
"We love going," Labit said. "Everything she cooks there is very good."
Labit and Borrelli, both large men, said they felt discriminated against because of their size.
"I was stunned, that somebody...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Houma Today is a regional news outlet serving Louisiana. While it provides relevant local news and has a good reputation within its community, it may not have the extensive resources or national recognition of larger outlets. It focuses on local issues, so while it can be reliable, it may not always be equipped to tackle more complex national or international news with the same rigor.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: Similar to evidence0, this evidence talks about men being charged extra at a buffet and subsequently banned. It shares elements about discrimination related to size and food consumption. However, it does not directly tie to John Pinette's comedic routine, making its relevance less significant to determining the truthfulness of the claim.

John Pinette, stand-up comic and ‘Seinfeld’ guest star, dies at 50
==================================================================
By Patrick Kevin Day
April 7, 2014 11:57 AM PT
*   
Share via Close extra sharing options
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   Copy Link URLCopied!
*   Print
Stand-up comedian John Pinette has died at age 50.
According to the Associated Press, the comedian, who was best known for his routine about an all-you-can eat Chinese buffet and for guest-starring on the series finale of “Seinfeld,” was found dead of natural causes in a Pittsburgh hotel room.
Pinette, who had struggled with his weight for decades, died of natural causes, according to the Allegheny County Medical Examiner’s office. Pinette’s personal doctor also signed off on the cause of death, meaning no autopsy is planned.
The comedian was most recently the host of the food series “All You Can Eat” on H2 in 2013, but he had the most exposure from him guest appearance on the finale episode of “Seinfeld.” He played a carjacking victim who is mocked by Jerry, Elaine, George and Kramer, which ends up getting them sent to jail. And jail is where the characters end up at the end of the hit series, which was a very controversial ending.
Advertisement
Pinette, who was named Stand-Up Comedian of the Year at the American Comedy Awards in 1999, recorded three stand-up specials in his career, “Show Me the Buffet,” “I’m Starvin’” and...[Content truncated]

It has a reputation for thorough reporting and fact-checking. However, like many news outlets, it can be subject to occasional biases, particularly in opinion pieces or coverage of politically charged events. Despite this, it is considered a reliable source for news and information.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence mentions John Pinette's well-known routine about an all-you-can-eat Chinese buffet, which is somewhat relevant to the lawsuit context. However, it does not explicitly relate to Golden Corral or provide insight into the specifics of the lawsuit, limiting its direct relevance.

QA.Question: Does John Pinette's video relate to the obese man's lawsuit against Golden Corral?
QA.Answer:
Yes, John Pinette's video does relate to the obese man's lawsuit against Golden Corral. Here are the reasons why:

1. **Buffet Theme**: Both the lawsuit and John Pinette’s comedic routine center around the concept of "all-you-can-eat" buffets. The man suing Golden Corral is doing so because he was expelled from the restaurant after spending an excessive amount of time (seven hours) eating, which he claims is part of the appeal of an all-you-can-eat buffet. Likewise, Pinette's comedy often revolves around his experiences and humorous frustrations with buffet dining, notably in his routine about a Chinese buffet where he is confronted about his eating habits.

2. **Humor and Exaggeration**: Pinette’s video exemplifies a humorous take on the experience of dining at a buffet, highlighting the absurdity of being reprimanded for eating at these establishments. The lawsuit similarly plays on societal perceptions and behaviors concerning obesity and food consumption, bringing a comedic element to a serious situation. The man in the suit claims he was treated unjustly at an all-you-can-eat buffet, drawing parallels to the humorous reprimands faced by Pinette in his performances.

3. **Public Perception of Buffet Customers**: The premise of both scenarios highlights societal expectations and perceptions of individuals who frequent buffets, particularly those who may be overweight. Pinette's comedic critiques often underscore the struggles of heavier individuals in dining contexts, which mirrors the sentiments expressed by the plaintiff in his legal grievances against Golden Corral due to his treatment when he exceeded typical buffet expectations.

Overall, both John Pinette's comedic discussions and the lawsuit reflect the larger cultural conversations surrounding buffet dining and the expectations placed on customers within these establishments.
